docs.snippet: After the financial crisis and the recent insider trading convictions of Raj Rajaratnam and Rajat Gupta, perhaps it is time to reconsider the plight of Jeffrey K. Skilling.     The former chief executive is serving a 24-year sentence arising from ...
docs.lead_paragraph: After the financial crisis and the recent insider trading convictions of Raj Rajaratnam and Rajat Gupta, perhaps it is time to reconsider the plight of Jeffrey K. Skilling. The former chief executive is serving a 24-year sentence arising from his conviction in a Houston trial of 19 counts after the stunning 2001 collapse of Enron. Until the financial crisis, Enron's bankruptcy was viewed as Exhibit A of corporate crime and executives run amok. After trial that lasted months, Mr. Skilling was convicted of securities fraud, among other crimes. Judge Sim Lake sentenced him to the low end of the recommended sentencing range after Mr. Skilling expressed remorse, asserting that he was ''innocent of these charges.''
docs.abstract: Steven M Davidoff Deal Professor column suggests that, in light of insider trading convictions of Raj Rajaratnam and Rajat Gupta, former Enron executive Jeffrey K Skilling's 24-year sentence appears increasingly unjustified; notes that Skilling awaits resentencing in light of a decision that overturned part of his conviction; urges the court to carefully reconsider. Drawing (M)

headline.main: In Insider and Enron Cases, Balancing Lies and Thievery

docs.snippet: The trial's make-or-break moment is near: Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay on the stand....
docs.lead_paragraph: Two of the country's best corporate salesmen are about to make the most important pitches of their lives. After 32 days of testimony from 22 witnesses, prosecutors rested their case last week in the criminal trial of Enron's former chief executives, setting the stage for the defense to take over as of Monday.

headline.main: In Enron Trial, A Calculated Risk

byline.original: By ALEXEI BARRIONUEVO and KURT EICHENWALD; Alexei Barrionuevo reported from Houston for this article, and Kurt Eichenwald from Dallas

docs.snippet: KENNETH L. LAY and his second in command, Jeffrey K. Skilling, were the public faces of Enron, painting a rosy picture of strong profits and healthy businesses. But as the facts began to tumble out, in the fall of 2001, the company swiftly collaps...
docs.lead_paragraph: KENNETH L. LAY and his second in command, Jeffrey K. Skilling, were the public faces of Enron, painting a rosy picture of strong profits and healthy businesses. But as the facts began to tumble out, in the fall of 2001, the company swiftly collapsed, taking with it the fortunes and retirement savings of thousands of employees. Tomorrow is the first day of the trial of Mr. Lay, who as founder and chairman is accused of seven counts of fraud and conspiracy, and Mr. Skilling, his chief executive, who faces dozens of counts, including fraud, conspiracy and insider trading.
docs.abstract: Article on 10 major figures in Enron Corp trial and where they are now; says chief financial officer Andrew Fastow, who pleaded guilty two years ago, faces 10 years in prison and is cooperating with federal prosecutors; holds Fastow could be first major witness at trial of Kenneth Lay and Jeffrey Skilling; Fastow and wife and children live in Houston; photo (S)

headline.main: 10 Enron Players: Where They Landed After the Fall

docs.snippet: In a recent impassioned public defense, Kenneth L. Lay may have been trying to fool himself about his role in Enron's downfall....
docs.lead_paragraph: THIS past Tuesday, Kenneth L. Lay, the disgraced former chairman of Enron, gave a remarkable speech before a hometown crowd in Houston. It's not every day that a prominent white-collar defendant makes an impassioned public defense barely a month before his criminal trial is set to start. That sort of thing tends to tick off prosecutors, not to mention judges. Then there was the matter of the speech's content. Aggressively self-pitying would sum up the tone of Mr. Lay's remarks. ''Of anything and everything that I could imagine might happen to me in my lifetime,'' Mr. Lay said, according to a text of his speech posted on his Web site, ''the one thing I would have never even remotely speculated about was that some day I would become entangled in our country's criminal justice system.''

headline.main: Living In The Enron Dream World

docs.snippet: Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron, was taken to a Manhattan hospital for observation yesterday after the police found him behaving erratically, law enforcement officials said.       Callers to the police reported that Mr. Sk...
docs.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron, was taken to a Manhattan hospital for observation yesterday after the police found him behaving erratically, law enforcement officials said. Callers to the police reported that Mr. Skilling was approaching people, pulling on their clothes and accusing them of being agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the officials said.
docs.abstract: Jeffrey K Skilling, former chief executive of Enron, is taken to New York Presbyterian Hospital for observation after police find him behaving erratically (S)

headline.main: Former Enron Chief in Police Incident

docs.snippet: Federal prosecutors are planning to seek a criminal indictment against Jeffrey K. Skilling, a former chief executive of Enron, people involved in the case said yesterday.      The timing of the charges is still in flux, these people said, although...
docs.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are planning to seek a criminal indictment against Jeffrey K. Skilling, a former chief executive of Enron, people involved in the case said yesterday. The timing of the charges is still in flux, these people said, although the current plan is that they will probably be announced Thursday or later. Throughout the Enron case, prosecutors have repeatedly filed charges under seal for a few days, announcing them only after the defendants have surrendered to the authorities.

headline.main: A Criminal Indictment Against Skilling of Enron Is Said to Be in the Works

docs.snippet: As Andrew S. Fastow, Enron's former chief financial officer, and his wife, Lea W. Fastow, grapple with criminal charges stemming from the federal investigation into the collapse of Enron, another couple in Houston is trying to get on with life as ...
docs.lead_paragraph: As Andrew S. Fastow, Enron's former chief financial officer, and his wife, Lea W. Fastow, grapple with criminal charges stemming from the federal investigation into the collapse of Enron, another couple in Houston is trying to get on with life as usual. Or at least a semblance of what might be considered normal for Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman and chief executive of Enron, and his wife, Linda P. Lay. Mr. Lay has recently been reducing his real estate holdings, having last month sold a 4,537-square-foot, log-and-stone home in Aspen, Colo., for $4.7 million. The Lays still occupy the entire 33rd floor of the Huntingdon Condominium in the River Oaks district of Houston -- not far from where the Fastows and other former Enron executives built sprawling Tudor-style homes.
docs.abstract: Former Enron Corp chairman and chief executive Kenneth L Lay and wife, Linda, are trying to get on with life as usual; recent activities noted (S)

headline.main: Private Sector; Life Goes On in Enronville
